node.title: Action system not working as intended
node.bodyText:
Dear all,
I wanted to use MOOSE action system to create custom syntax for my problem: ( precipitation growth problem in phase-field using KKS model). I created an action called "PrecipitateKKS" which will add the necessary variables for solving the KKS model namely c, w, eta, cs, and cl. But in my case, with and without action, I am getting different results. My solution does not converge when I use action.
My input script without using the action (explicity declaring variables):
kks_example_noflux.i.txt
My input script with action:
test_action.i.txt
Do you have any suggestions?
Thanks!
Sarita

My output from kks_example_noflux.i.txt (without using action) :

I'm a bit stumped here. Diff between the two inputs:
23,28c23,24
< [Variables]
<   # order parameter
<   [eta]
<     order = FIRST
<     family = LAGRANGE
<   []
---
> [PrecipitateKKS]
> []
30,33c26,30
<   # solute concentration
<   [c]
<     order = FIRST
<     family = LAGRANGE
---
> [ICs]
>   [ic_cs]
>     type = ConstantIC
>     value = 0.9
>     variable = cs
35,52c32,35
<
<   # chemical potential
<   [w]
<     order = FIRST
<     family = LAGRANGE
<   []
<
<   # Liquid phase solute concentration
<   [cl]
<     order = FIRST
<     family = LAGRANGE
<     initial_condition = 0.1
<   []
<   # Solid phase solute concentration
<   [cs]
<     order = FIRST
<     family = LAGRANGE
<     initial_condition = 0.9
---
>   [ic_cl]
>     type = ConstantIC
>     value = 0.1
>     variable = cl

Thank you, Daniel (@dschwen)!
I changed the variable order in my actions to { "eta" "c" "w" "cl" "cs" }.  And now it worked. I am getting the same output in both cases.
Thanks,
Sarita

node.title: Material Point Method in MOOSE (moved from mailing list)
node.bodyText:
This topic is moved from mailing list

On Tue, Nov 10, 2020 at 10:20 PM Jed Brown <jed@jedbrown.org> wrote:
Fande Kong <fdkong.jd@gmail.com> writes:

> On Tue, Nov 10, 2020 at 3:08 PM Nathan Miller <nathan.a.mill@gmail.com>
> wrote:
>
>> Hi All,
>>
>> I'm collaborating with the ASC PSAAP III program at CU Boulder ( see here
>> <https://www.colorado.edu/engineering/2020/10/01/engineering-leads-new-doe-predictive-science-academic-alliance-program-center-particulate>)
>> and they are using my micromorphic continuum mechanics code (
>> https://github.com/lanl/tardigrade ). As a part of the project, they
>> would like to try and use the material point method to solve the
>> micromorphic balance equations. Jed Brown, who is also collaborating on the
>> project, mentioned that PETSc's DMSwarm capabilities might be able to do
>> this but that it may require modification to libMesh or for MOOSE to
>> support some additional PETSc features that he wasn't sure you did.
>>
>
> Yes, we need to refactor DM a bit to bring DMSwarm in, and do some
> transfers between MOOSE MESH and PETSc DM. It is interesting for me.
> Unfortunately, we do not have any funded project that has such
> requirements right now. That being said, we might not get that really soon.
>
> Outside contributions are always welcome : -)

Thanks, Fande. We may be able to drive this forward under the PSAAP, but would
 like some guidance from the MOOSE team about how you would like to see it
 integrated. If you or other MOOSE developers have thoughts on that, perhaps
 we could discuss be email or a short screen-share meeting. This is a bit preliminary
 in that Nathan and myself are the only members of our current team who have
 experience with MOOSE, but I don't think either of us have free cycles to start
 implementing this right away. (We are hiring, if anyone is reading this and interested...)

The PSAAP center's needs include MPM for micromorphic mechanics (with Tardigrade)
 and MPM for grain-resolving simulation that is much more performance sensitive and
 will likely not use MOOSE. The project just started and strategy for the latter
 component is still in flux, but there's a good chance it will use DMSwarm
 (and upstream anything relevant).

@jedbrown want to introduce DMSwarm to MOOSE for MPM.
@idaholab/moose-team Any thoughts on how to integrate this capability?

Let's make sure to pull in @nathan-miller-LANL (I think I got this tag right). I think I could give a more educated answer if I was a little more educated on DMSwarm. I am always intrigued by a potential increase in integration between PETSc and libMesh/MOOSE. I think it would be a great idea to sit down and do the screen-share meeting that @jedbrown bought up. We would make sure to dial @roystgnr into that call as well
Yep, that's me. Let me know when you all want to try and to the web-meeting.

Nathan, go ahead to schedule a meeting next week or so.
It might be very really helpful if you could have a background introduction of this problem because we might not be familiar with this topic.

Dear all,
I followed with interest this discussion. I will have a post doctoral position starting (hopefully) soon where the candidate, among other things, would be asked to (at least try) to integrate Particle in Cell (PIC) capabilities to one of our moose based app, possibly based on DMSwarm from Petsc. This said, even if for a different applications than what discussed above, we would also be interested in any progress made in this field, and will also be willing to actively do some coding from our part. My comment  was meant on an informative level, but I would be glad to be informed if possible of any progress and/or decision about it. Thanks and sorry for stepping in.
Mauro

@fdkong, okay. I'll try and coordinate that.
@mcacace I'm glad to hear others are interested. Note that the method that we would want to implement MPM for would be a higher order continuum theory which includes as a subset classical (i.e. Cauchy) continuum mechanics. I would hope that what we would do would be at least tangentially applicable to your problem.
I am working on granular flow physics, and would like to see the development of MPM in MOOSE.
@wjin33 @loganharbour @friedmud and I have taken a look at mpm in moose if people want to join in on the effort

@GiudGiud et al: this is great news! As written in my previous post, we have some applications, for which usage of mpm (was considering more PIC) methods based on DMSwarm Petsc capabilities would be an asset. Would be interesting to learn more about the status and try to help the development.
Mauro

node.title: How do I create stress-free strain using eigenstrain?
node.bodyText:
I am building a simple model for mine simulations.
The workflow goes like this:

start with a uniform mesh with a number of blocks pre-defined; everything has the same Young's modulus at this point
apply gravity and solve for steady-state
import the result from pervious step, except in one of the pre-defined blocks, reduce Young's modulus by several orders of magnitude. again solve for steady-state, so that the mesh deforms.
import the result from previous step, except in the same block as before, increase Young's modulus to simulate backfill.  This results in the block pushing back against neighboring blocks because the initial strain is nonzero, which is not what I want.  Instead I would like to set a reference strain (or eigenstrain), which is equal to the previous strain at steady state, and calculate stress using E*(strain - eigenstrain).

I am stuck at step 4.  I think it should be possible using ComputeEigenstrain or ComputeVariableEigenstrain, but not sure about the syntax.
Any help?
@WilkAndy @Traiwit

Dear @jlinBE
The reduction of the stiffness tensor is not the same thing as introducing an eigenstrain.
For instance during plastic deformation you can have a large eigenstrain (plastic deformation) but still large stress and stiffness.
Or you can have stiffness reduction without any eigenstrain, for instance in a linear elastic model.
An example of code for stiffness reduction based on the temperature is in my repository:
https://github.com/ngrilli/c_pfor_am/blob/main/src/materials/ComputeElasticityTensorMelting.C
The choice between stiffness degradation and introducing eigenstrain depends on the specific phenomenon.
Best Regards,
Nicolò Grilli
National University of Singapore

About your point 4)
I suggest you to check for elastic-perfectly plastic material models, which is what you are describing.
It may be already available in the tensor mechanics module.

IsotropicPlasticityStressUpdate object with zero hardening should do that.
Your elements will deform permanently and will not apply stress on the rest of the geometry at the beginning
of your final step (step 4).

Hi @ngrilli,
Thank you for your suggestion, I tried to set zero hardening at the backfill block, but the simulation does not seem to converge. Not sure if I did anything wrong.
  [./isotropic_plasticity_backfill]
    type = IsotropicPlasticityStressUpdate
    yield_stress = 50.0
    hardening_constant = 0
    block = '1'
    use_displaced_mesh = true
  [../]
  [./return_stress_backfill]
  type = ComputeMultipleInelasticStress
     # tangent_operator = elastic
     inelastic_models = 'isotropic_plasticity_backfill'
     block = '1'
  [../]

I also attempted @WilkAndy suggestion from #16387: "At the start of each timestep, set the strain in certain elements (block ID) to zero. The "certain elements" are defined by another time-dependent Function, etc. Zeroing the strain should not impact the positions of the nodes in any element. Its purpose is to ensure the stress in these elements is zero (at the start of the timestep). This means an alternative would be to introduce a new reference strain, strain_ref, which is the strain in those elements at the start of the timestep, and calculate stress using stress = E * (strain - strain_ref). You haven't be able to achieve this, since there appears to be nothing in MOOSE that enables either of these ideas."
So for stress = E * (strain - strain_ref), I managed to maintain the deformed mesh using negative values of strain_ref in ComputeEigenstrain (https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/materials/CompositeEigenstrain.html).
[./eigen_backfill]
    type = ComputeEigenstrain
    eigenstrain_name = eigen_true
    eigen_base = '-3e-3 0 0 0 -0 0 0 0 -3e-3' 
    block = '1'
    use_displaced_mesh = true
  [../]
  [./eigen_therest]
    type = ComputeEigenstrain
    eigenstrain_name = eigen_true
    eigen_base = '0'
    block = '0'
    use_displaced_mesh = true
  [../]

-3e-3 is obtained from a trial and error method.
The question now is: how do we obtain the exact value of "strain_ref" so we can make sure that the backfill material doesn't push back the deformed mesh. should it be the value of the difference of strain before and after backfilling at that particular block? if so, how do I obtain such a value from 2 output files.
also 1 quick question, why doesn’t moose read second-order AuxVariables (monomial family) from an input file (previous simulation step) when using
  [./e11_aux]
    order = SECOND
    family = MONOMIAL
      initial_from_file_var = e11_aux
  [../]

it works fine when the order is constant.
Again, thank you for your time guys 👍

Dear @Traiwit
It's difficult to say what is your convergence problem.
Could you share the complete input file?
The first thing to check for the convergence problem in plasticity is the time step:
an elasto-plastic stress-strain curve must be solved with enough time steps,
maybe you can start with about 1000 time steps to reach 1% total strain or so.
Boundary conditions may also affect.
I suggest you start from the setting of this example with small strain:
https://github.com/idaholab/moose/blob/next/modules/tensor_mechanics/test/tests/strain_energy_density/rate_incr_model_elas_plas.i
Best Regards,
Nicolò Grilli
National University of Singapore

To simplify the question, is there a way that I can change the elasitcity_tensor (E and passion ration) of a block without changing the disp_x,y,z of that block from the previous step.
Thanks guys!

node.title: [ADKernel][Custom Kernel Problem][adCoupledGradient error]

node.bodyText:
Never mind!
I found my mistake in here
Can you please post the mistake so others searching the forum can see the answer?
was probably getParam and addParam missing their template specialization

node.title: Changing the name of an input file will affect the results ?!
node.bodyText:
Hey guys,
I've met a very weird problem recently.
I built an input file named 'test.i' and it could run well.
However, when I changed its name to 'test_th.i', there was an error 'segmental fault'.
If I change its name to 'test_t.i', it ran well again.... (The input file is attached)
test_t.txt
I find the problem very tricky...
The version of my MOOSE is: (Ubuntu 16.04)
commit db9be3f
Merge: 07f96ea 6984549
Author: moosetest bou...@inl.gov
Date:   Mon Mar 11 12:38:45 2019 -0600
Thanks a lot
Fengrui Xiang
It might help to see a list of all files in the directory you're running the simulation in.

Thanks for your reply.
Actually, there's nothing special in the directory. I just created a new App and activated the HeatCondution Modulus.

Closing as stale.
For the record, changing the name of the input file does not influence results.

node.title: segmentation fault
node.bodyText:
Hello everyone,
I am combining phase field and crystal plasticity on moose and the simulation seems to be working well for some time and then stops citing segmentation fault. I followed the debugging process given on moose framework website and built a debug object file and then ran the file again. I obtained the following error.
**Time Step 5, time = 0.023, dt = 0.008
[New Thread 0x7fffc6eb2700 (LWP 56706)]
[Thread 0x7fffc6eb2700 (LWP 56706) exited]
[New Thread 0x7fffc6eb2700 (LWP 56715)]
[Thread 0x7fffc6eb2700 (LWP 56715) exited]
[New Thread 0x7fffc6eb2700 (LWP 56719)]
[Thread 0x7fffc6eb2700 (LWP 56719) exited]
[New Thread 0x7fffc6eb2700 (LWP 56747)]
/export/apps/gcc-7.4.0/include/c++/7.4.0/debug/vector:417:
Error: attempt to subscript container with out-of-bounds index 0, but
container only holds 0 elements.
Objects involved in the operation:
sequence "this" @ 0x0x208f4c8 {
type = std::__debug::vector<RankTwoTensorTempl, std::allocator<RankTwoTensorTempl > >;
}
Program received signal SIGABRT, Aborted.
0x00007fffdeed1337 in raise () from /lib64/libc.so.6
Missing separate debuginfos, use: debuginfo-install glibc-2.17-292.el7.x86_64 infinipath-psm-3.3-26_g604758e_open.2.el7.x86_64 libX11-1.6.7-2.el7.x86_64 libXau-1.0.8-2.1.el7.x86_64 libfabric-1.7.0-1.el7.x86_64 libibumad-22.1-3.el7.x86_64 libibverbs-22.1-3.el7.x86_64 libnl3-3.2.28-4.el7.x86_64 libpsm2-11.2.78-1.el7.x86_64 librdmacm-22.1-3.el7.x86_64 libuuid-2.23.2-63.el7.x86_64 libxcb-1.13-1.el7.x86_64 numactl-libs-2.0.12-3.el7_7.1.x86_64 opensm-libs-3.3.21-2.el7.x86_64 zlib-1.2.7-18.el7.x86_64**
After typing where, I get a long list of notifications as below.
#1  0x00007fffdeed2a28 in abort () from /lib64/libc.so.6
#2  0x00007fffdfa54593 in __gnu_debug::_Error_formatter::_M_error (
this=0x61e420 <__gnu_debug::_Error_formatter::_M_at(char const*, unsigned int)::__formatter>)
at ../../../../../gcc-7.4.0/libstdc++-v3/src/c++11/debug.cc:1069
#3  0x00007ffff78d4c71 in std::__debug::vector<RankTwoTensorTempl, std::allocator<RankTwoTensorTempl                                                                                                                         > >::operator[] (this=0x208f4c8, __n=0) at /export/apps/gcc-7.4.0/include/c++/7.4.0/debug/vector:417
#4  0x00007ffff1e8f2a3 in CrystalPlasticitySlipRateGSS::calcFlowDirection (this=0x1337700, qp=2, flow_direction=...)
at /home/gnanasbr/temp_projects/moose/modules/tensor_mechanics/src/userobjects/CrystalPlasticitySlipRateGSS.C:162
#5  0x00007ffff1fc76a2 in FiniteStrainUObasedCP::computeQpStress (this=0x149c310)
at /home/gnanasbr/temp_projects/moose/modules/tensor_mechanics/src/materials/FiniteStrainUObasedCP.C:231
#6  0x00007ffff1fa39f2 in ComputeStressBase::computeQpProperties (this=0x149c310)
at /home/gnanasbr/temp_projects/moose/modules/tensor_mechanics/src/materials/ComputeStressBase.C:52
.......................................................................................................................
It goes to list a number of locations in other source code files.
I am not sure where I have gone wrong. As far as I can understand the error seems to be in the calcFlowDirection of the CrystalPlasticitySlipRateGSS user object.
How do I solve this problem?
Thanks,
Bala

Hi Bala,
I'm not an expert in this module however the debug trace seems to point to an out of bounds access in _flow_direction.
It's initialized with a material property in the constructor:
_flow_direction(getMaterialProperty<std::vector<RankTwoTensor>>(_name + "_flow_direction"))
Does that give you any hint of what is the issue? Can you share a MWE with the issue?
Guillaume
This type of error would lead me to believe that _flow_direction is not a reference when retrieved with getMaterialProperty

Hello Guillaume and Andrew,
I understand the issue. But I am not sure why it popped up as I have used the same FiniteCrystalUOBasedCP as shown in one of the examples. And forgive my ignorance, what is an MWE?
How do I retrieve _flow_direction as a  reference?
Thanks,
Bala
MWE = Minimum Working Example

To use a reference you need the "&" as follows in the header:
const MaterialProperty<T> & _D;
How is flow direction declared in the header?

@Bala-1005 We have not implemented the code in MOOSE to couple crystal plasticity with phase field fracture yet. Some external users have implemented their model in their own branch, and you might want to check with them, i.e. @ngrilli
At INL, we have been developing a variational consistent phase field fracture model for crystal plasticity , but it is not ready yet.
I see. Thank you for the information. But the phase-field coupling here is not for fracture but for solidification. Does it change anything?

What model are you using for solidification? Are you using the grain tracker? Our CP needs grain orientation information, that is usually provided by users as an input. If you have new grains being generated during solidification, I do not believe our CP can handle that case at this moment.

I am using KKS model and I am not using grain tracker. I have given grain orientation through interfaceorientationmaterial. And there are no new nucleation events. There is a small region where the phase field corresponds to solid and the phase variable evolves from this initial condition.

node.title: Function Plotting as AuxVariable
node.bodyText:
Is there an obvious way to plot the 3D results of a function? E.g. ive got a function which is applied as a body force, is there some way using AuxVariable that I can use to plot this data?
e.g.
  [heat]
    type = ADBodyForce
    variable = temp
    value = 1e6
    function = 'exp(-10*(y-0.13))'
    use_displaced_mesh = false
  []

Is there an obvious way to do this that I'm missing?

Hello
Use a functionAux and plot the variable you store the function values in.

node.title: w_advection
node.bodyText: w (z velocity) is not recognized in NSFVMomentumAdvection, INSFVMomentumPressure , FVDiffusion. What file will I need to modify in order to include w?

w should be the variable, not an extra argument, for INSFVMomentumPressure and FVDiffusion.
Could you please paste here your FVKernel syntax?
Thanks,
Guillaume

Thank you for you interest in potentially helping me to solve this issue. Here is the syntax for the FVKernels:
[FVKernels]
[mass]
type = INSFVMassAdvection
variable = pressure
advected_interp_method = ${advected_interp_method}
velocity_interp_method = ${velocity_interp_method}
vel = 'velocity'
pressure = pressure
u = u
v = v
w = w
mu = ${mu}
rho = ${rho}
[]
[u_advection]
type = INSFVMomentumAdvection
variable = u
advected_quantity = 'rhou'
vel = 'velocity'
advected_interp_method = ${advected_interp_method}
velocity_interp_method = ${velocity_interp_method}
pressure = pressure
u = u
v = v
w = w
mu = ${mu}
rho = ${rho}
[]
[u_viscosity]
type = FVDiffusion
variable = u
coeff = ${mu}
[]
[u_pressure]
type = INSFVMomentumPressure
variable = u
momentum_component = 'x'
p = pressure
[]
[v_advection]
type = INSFVMomentumAdvection
variable = v
advected_quantity = 'rhov'
vel = 'velocity'
advected_interp_method = ${advected_interp_method}
velocity_interp_method = ${velocity_interp_method}
pressure = pressure
u = u
v = v
mu = ${mu}
rho = ${rho}
[]
[v_viscosity]
type = FVDiffusion
variable = v
coeff = ${mu}
[]
[v_pressure]
type = INSFVMomentumPressure
variable = v
momentum_component = 'y'
p = pressure
[]
[w_advection]
type = INSFVMomentumAdvection
variable = w
advected_quantity = 'rhow'
vel = 'velocity'
advected_interp_method = ${advected_interp_method}
velocity_interp_method = ${velocity_interp_method}
pressure = pressure
u = u
v = v
w = w
mu = ${mu}
rho = ${rho}
[]
[w_viscosity]
type = FVDiffusion
variable = w
coeff = ${mu}
[]
[w_pressure]
type = INSFVMomentumPressure
variable = w
momentum_component = 'z'
p = pressure
[]
[]

It looks like you are missing w = 'w' for the v_advection kernel.
I ll check it more offline
It runs fine for me now when moving those kernels with the fix in an example problem
Wow! That is awesome! Thank you for your sage guidance on this problem.

node.title: Latest update libmesh compile failure

node.bodyText:
Hi
Does it work now?
DId you get the libmesh update through conda update --all ?
Guillaume

node.title: Simple mesh import problem
node.bodyText:
Hi Folks,
Weird one, Ive got a simple 2D mesh, with a sideset named pinned (which contains the nodes shown), I have a block defined called steel which contains all the triangles, as shown below.

When I run this
#Tensor Mechanics tutorial: the basics

[Mesh]
  type = FileMesh 
  file = '../mesh/beam.e'
  construct_side_list_from_node_list = true
[]
 
[GlobalParams]
  displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
[]
  
[Variables]
  [disp_x]
  []
  [disp_y]
  []
[]

I get a segfault,
0x00007ffff27cd581 in libMesh::BoundaryInfo::build_node_list(libMesh::BoundaryInfo::NodeBCTupleSortBy) const ()
   from /home/adavis/opt/moose/scripts/../libmesh/installed/lib/libmesh_opt.so.0
Missing separate debuginfos, use: dnf debuginfo-install hwloc-libs-2.2.0-1.fc33.x86_64 libX11-1.6.12-3.fc33.x86_64 libXau-1.0.9-4.fc33.x86_64 libgcc-10.2.1-9.fc33.x86_64 libgfortran-10.2.1-9.fc33.x86_64 libgomp-10.2.1-9.fc33.x86_64 libpng-1.6.37-6.fc33.x86_64 libquadmath-10.2.1-9.fc33.x86_64 libstdc++-10.2.1-9.fc33.x86_64 libxcb-1.13.1-5.fc33.x86_64 zlib-1.2.11-23.fc33.x86_64
(gdb) bt
#0  0x00007ffff27cd581 in libMesh::BoundaryInfo::build_node_list(libMesh::BoundaryInfo::NodeBCTupleSortBy) const ()
   from /home/adavis/opt/moose/scripts/../libmesh/installed/lib/libmesh_opt.so.0
#1  0x00007ffff6e21d4e in MooseMesh::buildNodeList() () from /home/adavis/opt/moose/framework/libmoose-opt.so.0
#2  0x00007ffff6e22780 in MooseMesh::update() () from /home/adavis/opt/moose/framework/libmoose-opt.so.0
#3  0x00007ffff6e22d4a in MooseMesh::prepare(bool) () from /home/adavis/opt/moose/framework/libmoose-opt.so.0
#4  0x00007ffff70c6f01 in SetupMeshCompleteAction::act() () from /home/adavis/opt/moose/framework/libmoose-opt.so.0
#5  0x00007ffff70c1036 in Action::timedAct() () from /home/adavis/opt/moose/framework/libmoose-opt.so.0
#6  0x00007ffff70c9619 in ActionWarehouse::executeActionsWithAction(std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> > const&) ()
   from /home/adavis/opt/moose/framework/libmoose-opt.so.0
#7  0x00007ffff70cabcf in ActionWarehouse::executeAllActions() () from /home/adavis/opt/moose/framework/libmoose-opt.so.0

#9  0x00007ffff7a79816 in MooseApp::run() () from /home/adavis/opt/moose/framework/libmoose-opt.so.0
#10 0x00000000004032ab in main ()
(gdb) quit

Anything obvious that Im doing wrong?

Nothing obvious to me.
With any luck the debug backtrace might give enough information if you could re-run with a debug build.
Guillaume
